newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN PM WARNS AGAINST RENAULT VILVOORDE OPTIMISM.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN PM WARNS AGAINST RENAULT VILVOORDE OPTIMISM.

text.p: Belgian Prime Minister Jean-Luc Dehaene warned on Thursday against over-optimism in the search for a solution to the controversial decision by French car-maker Renault to close its Belgian assembly plant.

He told the Senate it was important the independent expert, named by Renault on Tuesday to look into the decision and the viability of the Vilvoorde plant near Brussels, should be given all the necessary information on the plant and Belgian law.

Dehaene reiterated the appointment of Danielle Kaisergruber was "an opening," but added the final decision on the future of Vilvoorde was one for the French company and not for the Paris government, which has a 46 percent stake in the car-maker.
Kaisergruber toured the Vilvoorde plant on Thursday and met management and union officials, but made no statements afterwards.

Staff at the plant, still fighting to preserve the bulk of the 3,100 jobs, plan to remain on strike at least until Monday. They downed tonday, ahead of Tuesday's meetings of the Renault board and shareholders.

Renault said on February 27 it planned to close Vilvoorde in July as part of an essential reorganisation of its European car assembly operations, which are far more scattered and costly than those of its bigger rivals in the European industry.
The car-maker cited falling demand and tough competition.
The latest car sales figures for western Europe also gave no reason for optimism.

The European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA) said on Thursday West European car sales fell by 1.9 percent in May compared with the same month last year, partly reflecting weaker-than-expected economic conditions.
French cales slumped by a larger than average 23.1 percent.
